March 12, 1926.
My dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
You will be interested, I am sure, in the
following quotation from a letter from Dr. Walcott to
Dr. Beeuwkes dated at Accra December 19, 1925:

“While on the trip over to Sekondi, on
November 10th, I visited the la-
goon and examined perhaps 50 crab
holes along its shore. On return-
ing for this survey, two visits
on different days resulted in the
capture of 4 adult Aedes irritans
after a search of 75 crab holes
and no larvae in the lagoon which
had continued below grass level.
Confirmation of the variety of mos-
quitoes found was given by Mrs.
Summers Connal whom it was my good
fortune to meet again in Accra. I
am very doubtful of the correctness
of the report by Doctor Lorena of
the breeding, in 1923, of Aedes
aegypti in the lagoon and crab holes
due to all other suitable places in
Saltpond having been rendered una-
vailable to this mosquito”.

Also in the following paragraph from Dr. Beeuwkes
which refers to Dr. Walcott's investigation of crab-
hole breeding:

“During his previous visit here on November
10th, Walcott investigated the proposi-
tion of crab-hole breeding along the shore
of the lagoon and while making the present
survey carried out further investigations.
He examined in all approximately 125 crab
holes and captured only four adult Aedes
irritans mosquitoes, and found no larvae
at any time in the lagoon where the water
is now below the grass level.”

I wonder if you happened to see the article by
Dr. Hanson entitled “His Personal Experiences in an Attack
of Yellow Fever” which appeared in the Journal of the
American Medical Association of February 20, 1926 (Page
548)? In it he makes a fine reference to your Father.

I hope that your health continues to improve and
that you are continuing to pay some attention to it.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, F. F. Russell Miss Laura A. Carter
2121 California Street, N.W.
Washington
D. C.
